Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Balancing the Portfolio: Efficiency and Productivity of Federal Biomedical R&D Funding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This cross-disciplinary, cross-institution collaborative research project combines economic analysis with state-of-the-art methods from statistical machine learning, to assess the relative efficiency and efficacy of research and development expenditures across the U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH) portfolio of extramural projects. The novel combination of econometrics, topic modeling, and document classification permits analysis of massive collections of grant abstracts and scientific publications, identification of latent research topics present in NIH-funded research, assessment of possible spillover effects across research topics, and evaluation of causal linkages between changes in NIH funding by research topic and scientific advances. Two specific research outcomes are considered: scientific publications, classified by topic; and pharmaceutical innovation, measured by drugs entering into clinical development to treat specific diseases. Planned research also includes refinement of existing economic theory to produce normative evaluations of the allocation of public research spending.

Broader Impacts: This research will inform key policy questions related to federal funding of biomedical research. First, fiscal austerity requires careful attention to the nation's research portfolio and investments. This project will describe and evaluate the productivity of those investments, as a first step towards policy recommendations for rebalancing the portfolio, to maximize society's expected return on investment. Second, if NIH funding for basic research spurs increased pharmaceutical innovation, NIH possesses an important policy tool to promote pharmaceutical R&D in areas of high therapeutic importance or significant health disparity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH) invests over $30 billion each year in scientific research and development, developing innovations to improve population health and reduce the burden of disease. As a result of this investment it is important to develop methods to quantify and understand how such funding is being allocated, for example to help determine policies for equitable practices in the allocation of funding resources across different diseases. 


This research project investigated the use of statistical text mining techniques to automatically extract information about changes in funding patterns using publicly-available NIH funding data. In particular, the project focused on analyzing data describing approximately 150,000 research grants funded by the National Cancer Institute (NCI) between 1994 and 2013. Each record in this database includes the text of the grant title and abstract, the amount of funding for the grant, a list of publications resulting from the grant, plus other relevant information. A subset (about 20%) of these records have been tagged by the NIH with standardized topic labels, known as Research, Condition, and Disease Categorization (RCDC) topics. Examples of RCDC topics include disease categories such as Brain Cancer and Liver Disease, broad research areas such as Biotechnology and Gene Therapy, as well as general categories associated with research grants such as Clinical Trials.


Statistical text mining algorithms were developed as part of this research project that used the subset of NCI grants already tagged to learn a statistical model that could estimate the degree to which a document is associated with any of 88 different RCDC topics. Using this approach, the statistical model was used to generate the likelihood of each of the RCDC topics for all of the 150,000 NCI research grants, and in turn, to produce a 20-year time-series of the estimated prevalence and amount of funding associated with each topic. In addition, approximately 200,000 abstracts from related scientific literature over the same 20-year period were also mapped into the same set of 88 topics using the same statistical approach. 


The resulting data has provided public-policy analysts with a rich new data set that allows them to quantitatively analyze how funding for cancer research has evolved over the past 20 years in the United States. The statistical text mining methodologies developed as part of this project can also be used to analyze funding data available for other Institutes within the NIH, and in principle can be applied to databases from any public funding agency. More broadly, the methods developed have the potential to be useful across a variety of disciplines where there is a need to automatically analyze textual data over time. One application for example would be to assist technology analysts in analyzing patterns over time in the patent literature, to help predict and understand how technology both in the US and abroad.
